displayed_text: Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more
Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: No. What they’re trying to do is figure out whether it does work better than… Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Than that or the um Xtandi plus the other pill. So that’s what the study is. Xtandi is already approved for… Doctor: I want to be part of this discussion too. Doctor: Of course I am. I’m the one directing it. Patient: How are you doing? Doctor: I’m alright. How are you Mr. H___? Nice to see you. How are you? Family Member: Good to see you again. Doctor: Yes, definitely. No you’re good. Healthcare Professional: I was just explaining… Family Member: There’s a chair over there. Healthcare Professional: I’m sorry?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: In a perfect world, I should be able to print that so that you don’t have to go through that. Patient: That’s okay. Doctor: I can place it for - over the - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So uh we’ll place an order. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Do you want to do it in two months or three months? Do you have any preference? Patient: Well when am I going to see you again? Doctor: January would be reasonable. How about three months from now? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do it about a week or two before? If I see you in mid-January?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so I think it’s worth a go at least to think about it. Patient: I should, now will I be, if I, like if I go to the hotel and get a ride over. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I went back to the hotel. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Would I be okay to like to go back there by myself? Doctor: Oh, yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - is there enough of a channel for you to pee on our own? Doctor: So all of that – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - is what urologists do. Patient: Right, I know. So anyway, I have it scheduled. Family Member: Hormones - Uh is he getting more medicine today? Doctor: Well he got that shot; that shot lasts for three months Family Member: OHH! Patient: For three months? Oh, okay. I thought it was for three weeks. Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Um and yeah, you’ve got the visit with Dr___, and his team – Family Member: Catheter Doctor: - to change the catheter – Patient: Right. Doctor: - but if you don’t need that because you’re doing it locally - Patient: Right. Doctor: He’s just so you know because I guess your family and - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - his family are all sort of active, you know he’s very happy to you know be a part of that process, but also if you’re getting it locally and getting it done - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so I’m not going to put any additional appointments in here. I’ll let D take it over from here. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited.

Patient: Okay, so you’ll know whether the castration is working or not with the hormone Family Member: After the three months of the chemo and hormone pills, how does the hormone deprivation continue? Is that – it starts now? Okay. Doctor: About every three months. Family Member: I’m sorry if you said this, but how long does the radiation go? Doctor: The radiation takes two months, coming to the hospital five days a week. I forget where you live. Patient: C___ Doctor: So you can actually go to G____. Patient: Okay, perfect. Family Member: Oh wow! Doctor: I’m sure G____has a machine. Family Member: And they do as good a job to here? Doctor: Oh yeah, same people, same machines.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: You had a shot in June. So your next one isn’t, you know, until September. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum.

Patient: Mass. Doctor: Which we know because you had a biopsy in the past which proved that to be so. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Doctor: And uh the bone is not that clear whether there’s anything in there. To me it doesn’t look like there’s any cancer in there. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: It looks like you have arthritis all the usual goodies that we’ve talked about, but mostly everything is here. Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there… Doctor: Yeah, yeah… Patient: …from a car wreck. Doctor: And it wasn’t even that that prominent. Patient: You’re gonna see stuff there. Doctor: You got that, I saw that, yep. So the good part is it’s, not the good part but, it’s primarily localized right here. So the question is what to do. Now one, I know you’ve asked about well why can’t we just go in and radiate or do some stuff there. Patient: It wasn’t quite that simplistic.

Patient: And that’s the um I guess that’s what’s (pause3secs) Healthcare Professional: Right, you just want to do what you have to, yes, exactly. No, we get that. Patient: Because I know there are so many side effects. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So if where where the - we’re looking is probably radiation and sort of like not a complete hormone but like some sort of and I’m probably going to get some sort of a modified sense of a hormonal thing. So I’ll still have some effects of it, but in that effect so that the radiation if we do that part when we target it on what we know where it’s landed, the hormonal will be sort of be keeping everything else at bay at this point. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so I think that’s a trial. Uh I’m trying to think. I mean, we, we had a, I’m just thinking of one of the study nurses. There’s also some evidence that folks who uh have been on enzalutamide like you are, there was a group that started giving people immune therapy with enzalutamide, even though the enzalutamide was not working. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They kept them on the enzalutamide and added this immune drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And they had occasional patients who have very dramatic effects. Uh probably about twenty-five percent of the patients they treat. So we have a trial. I’ve got to figure out if we can finesse it because you’re not on enzalutamide any more. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It almost would require us putting you back on it, having demonstrated it doesn’t work, and then adding this drug, which is kind of weird. Occasionally, however, we have seen men after testosterone because potentially you could respond to enzalutamide. I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s a little bit confusing but that’s another possible trial. Patient: That’s the extent, enzalutamide? Doctor: Yeah, right. So I mean you didn’t respond.

Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse. Patient: So I’ll only be in Texas for now long? Doctor: One or two days. Patient: A couple of days? Doctor: Yeah. The scan takes literally two hours. Patient: Stay, stay in the hospital or is-? Doctor: No. I think they put you in a hotel.

Patient: No. Doctor: That’s good. Um. Platelets are normal. (pause) Patient: Mmmm. I didn’t see that. (pause) Doctor: Six five oh, yeah, two months ago. So, you said you did read the scans or? Patient: Well, I saw them, you know, in the lab works screen. I didn’t, I didn’t look at the —- I mean, I couldn’t see the bone scans or anything like that. They don’t post those. Now, the PSA wasn’t posted when I looked at it, uh, this morning. Doctor: Umm, (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right.
